title: Can I file for bankruptcy if I have a judgment & it stipulates that it cannot be discharged if I file for bankruptcy.
question: I have a judgement that stipulates that the amount owed cannot be discharged if i file for bankruptcy
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Debt,Nondischargeable debts,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan
answers: You cannot waive the right to file bankruptcy. The stipulation, which appears in every settlement agreement I have ever seen, is unenforceable as a matter of law.

Even if you have one debt that is nondischargeable in a Chapter 7 Bankruptcy, that does NOT mean that you can't file a Chapter 7 Bankruptcy. If you do file a Chapter 7 Bankruptcy, ALL of your debts should be listed. The bankruptcy Court decides what is dischargeable and what is not. Lots of people have 1 or more nondischargeable debts. They still file Chapter & Bankruptcies.

Of course, you can always use a Chapter 13 Bankruptcy to get control of nondischargeable creditors and force them to take reasonable payments. Good luck.
Generally, such a stipulation is unenforceable but more details are needed to give you useful advice. Send me a copy of the document and call to discuss in particular.
